data.title: How to troubleshoot screen and picture issues on your Sony TV
data.meta_description: Learn how to recognise and troubleshoot screen and picture issues on your Sony TV. Find out more about common screen issues, how to know if you're dealing with physical damage, how to adjust the picture settings, and how to get in touch with our support team.
data.text:
IMPORTANT: This article applies only to specific products and/or operating systems. Check Applicable Products and Categories for details.

How to troubleshoot TV screen issues

Picture and display issues on your TV screen may be caused by many different factors, including (but not limited to) physical damage, a poor network or cable connection, changes to the picture settings, and outdated software. If you notice any unusual symptoms on your TV screen, the troubleshooting steps in this article may be able to help.

Click or tap a topic below to jump to the relevant section:

Common TV screen issues

Before you start

General troubleshooting guide

How to adjust the TV settings

Contact us

Example images of different screen issues

Common TV screen issues

Click or tap the blue underlined text to see an example image.

Black screen:

The screen turns completely black, even when the sound can still be heard.

Horizontal/vertical lines or bands:

There are noticeable lines or bands in different colours (e.g. red, green, blue, white, black, etc.).

If there is a clear point of impact, these lines could indicate physical damage.

Mosaic or blocky images:

The picture appears scrambled or garbled.

Stains or tinted areas:

There is a discoloured patch or stain of color on the screen (green, purple, red, etc.).

This discolouration could be a result of image retention (screen burn-in).

Unclear or unfocused picture:

The picture appears blurry, hazy, or dull.

Double or "ghost" images:

The TV image looks like there's a mirror image that's slightly out of sync.

Cloudy or patchy images:

The TV picture looks patchy or blotchy when watching very dark scenes.

A screen that's too dark or too bright:

The contrast of the screen is too low or high.

Abnormal colours:

The TV image colours seem overexposed or inverted (e.g. the brightest colours turn dark).

The display turns grey while watching content.

→ Return to the top of the page

Before you start

Check your TV for physical damage

These troubleshooting steps apply to most, if not all, picture issues, unless you're dealing with physical damage.

If your TV shows physical damage, please book a repair at your nearest Sony Authorized Service Centre.

Your TV may be damaged if the picture issue is always present on the screen regardless of what you're watching.

Physical damage lines are usually both horizontal and vertical with a visible point of impact.

Confirm if the picture issue is limited to a specific situation (e.g. a particular app or connected device)

If yes, the program, game, or video content you are watching may be broadcast or recorded in an aspect ratio that appears stretched or distorted.

For example, some movie content is recorded in a 21:9 cinema format that will display with black bars above and below the picture when viewed on a widescreen (16:9) TV.

In this case, the issue is likely with the app or device rather than the TV itself. Check the settings of the app or device to confirm:

Try to switch the TV input.

Or, check the resolution and refresh rate settings on the connected device (e.g., computer, gaming console) and ensure they match what your TV supports.

If needed, change the current settings to the recommended ones for your TV.

Are you dealing with a pixel-related issue?

There may be a small number of pixels that do not change color, which is a normal occurrence for all LCD/OLED displays.

These pixels stay on the screen but are noticeable only while an all-white or all-black picture is shown, and should not be noticeable during normal viewing conditions.

Some pixels can appear dead or defective if there is debris on the screen.

Sometimes these dead or defective pixels will correct themselves over time. However, if they don't, try cleaning the screen thoroughly with a soft dry cloth to confirm whether or not the issue is due to a dead or defective pixel, or if it's due to dirt or debris on the screen.

Refer to this FAQ for more details: Pixels on the LCD or OLED screen appear dark or as bright red, green or blue dots.

→ Return to the top of the page

General troubleshooting guide

Click or tap the section(s) related to your TV screen issue.

Restart (reset) the TV

A TV reset can help resolve a number of screen issues.

To perform a power cycle of your TV:

Turn the TV off.

Unplug the power cord (mains lead) from the electrical outlet.

Leave the TV unplugged for 30 seconds.

Plug the power cord back into the outlet.

Turn the TV on.

Refer to this FAQ for more details: How to reset your Sony TV.

Notes:

If the issue persists, try plugging the power cord into a different electrical outlet.

If the TV is connected to an external hard drive (HDD), remove the HDD and try the reset procedure again.

These steps may also apply to devices connected to the TV.

Adjust the location of the TV

It's important to find a good location to set up your TV as certain factors such as excessive sunlight and electromagnetic waves can affect your TV's functionality.

Follow these tips to help find the right spot for your TV and avoid the risk of picture issues.

Keep your TV away from direct sunlight

Too much sun exposure can cause permanent damage to the TV screen, including discoloration, fading, and image retention or burn-in.

Keep other electronics away from the TV

The majority of electronic devices emit electromagnetic waves, which can interfere with the HDMI signal between your TV and connected external device such as a gaming console or set-top box.

A faulty HDMI signal can lead to issues such as black screen and/or No Signal error message to appear on the TV.

Be mindful of household appliances such as laptop computers, microwaves, and Wi-Fi routers. Move them further away from the TV if necessary.

Check the cable connection

You may experience TV screen issues if the cable you're using to connect the TV to an external device (such as a gaming console or set-top box) is damaged or defective, or if the cable isn't properly secured to either the TV or connected device. Sometimes, even using the wrong HDMI port or TV input can create a picture error.

The following steps can help you troubleshoot issues with your HDMI cable connection(s).

Make sure the cable connecting your TV to the device is in good condition.

Replace the cable if it's outdated or shows signs of damage (e.g., exposed wires, bent connectors).

Check that the cable isn't loose and is securely plugged into both the TV and device.

Cleaning around or near the cable can sometimes dislodge it or make it loose.

Re-attach the cable to both the TV and device to ensure a secure connection.

Use high-quality HDMI cables with good shielding.

This will help protect against HDMI signal interference caused by electromagnetic wave emissions.

If you are using an HDMI/MHL connection and the screen turns black or the image doesn't display correctly, try the following:

Disconnect the HDMI/MHL cable and connect it again.

Unplug the power cord (mains lead) of the connected device and plug it back in, or reboot the device.

Ensure your TV is set to the correct video (HDMI) input to receive the signal from the device connected to the HDMI port.

If there is no input signal, try connecting the cable to another HDMI port on the TV.

Verify that the HDMI-connected device is outputting a signal in a format compatible with the TV.

Check your product manual for more details on compatible signal formats.

If the issue persists, try using a different connection method if possible (e.g., Bluetooth pairing).

Check the Wi-Fi connection

Certain screen and picture issues may be caused by a faulty Wi-Fi connection. The options below may help resolve the issue:

Restart your router or check the service provider's website(s) for more information.

If you're dealing with a poor Wi-Fi signal, you may need to reset or relocate the router, modem, or TV.

Check the following links for more details:

For Android TVs

For non-Android TVs

To use Google Assistant, your TV must be connected to a Wi-Fi network.

If you press the Microphone or Google Assistant button on the remote control without a network connection, a grey screen will appear.

The grey screen will disappear automatically after a few seconds.

Refer to this FAQ for more details: How to & Troubleshooting for your TV internet connection.

Perform a picture test on your TV

Press the HELP button on the remote control.

You can also open the Help screen via the HOME menu. Depending on your TV model:

Select HOME → (Apps) → Help.

Select HOME → (Help).

Under Top support solutions, select Problem diagnosis.

If this option isn't available, proceed to Step 3.

Select Picture/Sound symptoms.

Select Start.

Your TV will play a series of images and sounds to test the display and audio.

To cancel the test, press the BACK button on the remote.

The message Picture and sound test is complete! will appear on your TV screen at the end of the test.

Select Finish to end the test.

To repeat the test, select Restart the test or Start again.

Check the Screen mirroring function

A blurry picture on the TV screen could be caused by enabling Screen mirroring. Keep the following in mind when using this feature:

The image may not display correctly depending on the output resolution of the screen mirroring device and the resolution of the played file.

For example, content played in a low resolution (480p or 720p) may not show clearly on the screen.

Try playing high-resolution content (1080p) to see if this resolves the issue.

Try to connect the BRAVIA TV and screen mirroring device using a Mobile High-Definition Link (MHL) HDMI cable.

Note: Some models do not support an MHL connection. Check the TV manual for compatibility and specifications.

Refer to this FAQ for more details: Why does a blurry picture appear during Screen mirroring?

Prevent image retention (OLED TVs)

Image retention occurs when an image remains on the screen for long and extensive periods, or if the same image is displayed repeatedly over and over again. This causes a temporary or permanent image to linger on the screen even after you've changed the channel or turned the programme off, almost like a residual shadow. However, there are steps you can take to prevent image retention on your TV.

Perform a panel calibration

Press the Quick Settings ( or ) button on the remote control.

Select Settings → System → Retail mode settings → Picture reset mode → On.

Turn the TV off and then back on using the AC power cord.

Before running the panel calibration, a dialogue will appear on the screen. Start the panel calibration from this dialogue.

Notes:

The TV automatically undergoes a panel calibration a few hours after it's been turned off with the remote control.

If Picture reset mode is On, and you disconnect and reconnect the power cord and then turn the TV on, it will go into Standby mode for approximately 10 minutes to perform the panel calibration.

The TV will restart once the calibration is complete.

After this procedure, you can set Picture reset mode back to Off.

A panel calibration can also enhance the TV screen when watching dark scenes.

Leave the TV off for one night

We recommend performing these steps after each use of the TV:

Press the Power button on the remote control to turn the TV off.

Leave it off for one night (at least 6 hours).

Avoid using (static) images that are susceptible to image retention

This includes:

Photos

On-screen menus

Program guides

Static images with clocks, logos, or bright colours (including white)

Turn the on-screen display (OSD) off

Turning the on-screen display off can help reduce the appearance of static images on the TV screen.

Follow the steps below to disable this feature:

Press the DISPLAY button on the supplied remote control.

Set the OSD to off.

Refer to this FAQ for more details: What is image retention on OLED TVs and how to avoid it.

Update the TV software

It's important to update your TV software on a regular basis as it includes key features, applications, bug fixes, and improvements necessary to keep your TV running smoothly. It can also help resolve a variety of picture and screen issues you may be experiencing.

To enable automatic software updates for your TV:

Connect the TV to the Internet.

Set Automatically check for update or Automatic Software Download to On.

With this feature enabled, updates will automatically download when your TV is in Standby mode.

Refer to this FAQ for more details: How to perform a software update on your TV.

→ Return to the top of the page

How to adjust the TV settings

It's possible the picture settings of your TV are not ideal for the content you're watching (e.g., contrast and brightness issues). If you've changed the picture settings before, we recommend resetting them to default values. Otherwise, you can try optimising the settings for the content you're watching.

Click or tap the sections below to adjust the different picture settings on your TV:

Picture reset mode

If the Picture reset mode of your OLED TV is set to On during a power reset, the TV screen will go completely black. This happens because the TV enters Standby mode when performing a panel calibration. The screen will return to normal after about ten minutes once the calibration is complete.

If you don't want to run the panel calibration, you can disable the Picture reset mode:

Access the Settings screen.

Using the Quick Settings button (for models released in 2019 or later):

On the remote control, press the (Quick Settings) button.

Select (Settings).

Using the HOME button (for other models):

On the remote control, press the HOME button.

Select (Settings).

The next steps will depend on your TV menu options:

Select System → Retail mode settings → Picture reset mode.

Select Device Preferences → Retail mode settings → Picture reset mode.

Select Retail mode settings → Picture reset mode.

Select Off.

Eco/Timer settings

If your TV goes into Standby mode after a while, or if the screen turns black while the sound can still be heard, you may need to adjust the Eco/Timer settings on your TV.

How to adjust the Eco settings

For Android TVs:

Press the HOME button.

Select Settings → Power → Eco.

Choose your desired option.

For non-Android BRAVIA TVs:

Go to the HOME menu.

Select System Settings → Eco.

Choose your desired option.

How to adjust the Timer settings

For Android TVs:

Press the HOME button.

Select Settings → Date & time → Automatic date & time.

For non-Android BRAVIA TVs:

Go to the HOME menu.

Select System Settings → Clock/Timers.

Refer to this FAQ for more details: Change your Eco/Timer settings.

Light Sensor

Almost all Sony LCD TVs have a Light Sensor feature, which optimises the screen brightness accordingly depending on the ambient light in your room. For example, the screen brightness will decrease in a darker room and increase in a brighter room.

You can reduce the amount of power your TV consumes by using an optimised picture brightness.

Follow the steps below to set the Light Sensor to On:

Press the HOME button on your remote control.

The next steps will depend on your TV menu options:

Select Settings → System settings → ECO / Light Sensor → On.

Select Settings → Display → Picture → Light Sensor → On.

LED Dynamic Control

If your TV has the LED Dynamic Control feature, it should always be turned on. Keep this is mind when adjusting your TV settings, as it may switch off when the Picture setting is set to Custom.

You can resolve this by following one of the procedures below:

Press the Options button on your remote control.

Select Picture.

Change the Picture setting from Custom to Standard.

Or

Leave the set in Custom mode (but within the picture settings).

Select Advanced Settings.

Change LED Dynamic Control from OFF to Standard or High.

Picture Mode

Certain picture issues may be resolved by changing Picture Mode to Standard:

Press the HOME button on the remote control.

Select Settings:

Using the Quick Settings button (for models released in 2019 or later)

Press the (Quick Settings) button on the remote control.

Select (Settings).

Using the HOME button (for other models)

Press the HOME button on the remote control.

Select (Settings) in the top menu.

Select Display & Sound or Display.

Select Picture → Picture Mode → Standard.

Note: Standard is recommended for home use and when viewing content that often displays the TV channel logos.

Brightness level

If the picture appears too bright or too dark, you may need to adjust the brightness level of the TV screen:

Press the HOME button on the remote control.

Select Settings → Display → Picture → Brightness.

Choose your preferred brightness level.

Wide mode

If you notice black bars on the TV screen, adjusting the Wide mode may help resolve this issue.

Open the (Settings) menu.

Using the (Quick Settings) button (for models released in 2019 or later)

Press the (Quick Settings) button on the remote control.

Select (Settings).

Using the HOME button (for other models)

Press the HOME button on the remote control.

Select (Settings) in the top menu.

Select Display & Sound or Display.

Select Screen.

Select Wide mode.

Select Wide zoom, Full, or Zoom.

Advanced settings

To access the Advanced settings menu on your TV:

Using the ACTION MENU button:

Select the ACTION MENU → Picture adjustments → Advanced settings.

Using the Quick Settings button:

Select (Quick Settings) → Settings → Display & Sound → Advanced settings.

Note: If Advanced settings does not appear, select your desired option using the Brightness, Colour, Clarity, or Motion settings

To reset the picture settings from the Advanced settings menu:

On the remote control, press the HOME button.

Select (Settings).

The next steps will depend on your TV menu options:

Select Display & Sound → Picture → Reset picture settings for *Standard → Yes.

* The setting name may be different depending on the selected Picture mode.

Select Display & Sound → Picture → Advanced settings → Reset.

Select Display → Picture → Advanced settings → Reset.

Select BRAVIA Settings → Picture adjustment → Advanced → Reset.

→ Return to the top of the page

Contact us

If the issue persists even after following the troubleshooting steps in this article, you may need to get in touch with our Support team.

Please take clear pictures of the issue you're experiencing.

The pictures must be taken under normal lighting conditions with the screen displaying content you would normally watch on the TV.

Ensure you have taken a picture showing all four TV corners.

Take a close-up picture focusing on the affected area(s) of the screen.

Once you've taken the pictures, please contact us.
